results.title: It wasn't me
results.creator_credit: Eddie Moses, John Honey, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1978 film consists of a short narrative demonstrating the need for observing industrial safety standards on building sites. The film’s cast of characters includes a wealthy contractor, a negligent foreman, a disgruntled safety warden, a foreign labourer and a department inspector, as they attempt to reconstruct what happened to a missing worker following a trench collapse. Each of the characters avoids responsibility in their roles and blames the others for the accident. Presented as a dramatic short with points of comedy (though this is mainly through the slapstick representation of an Italian worker who doesn’t speak English), the film emphasises the importance of all members of the workforce taking responsibility for upholding safe practices on site.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Peter Aanensen, Frank Bansel, Brendan Cassidy, Cul Cullen, Cliff Ellen, Don Glover, Peter Kay, Kevin Lacey, Robert Larkins, Sue Ellen Peers, Robert Ward

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, David Plummer, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't lose your grip
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1961 film illustrates safe methods for handling and storage of rolled steel joists, angles and plates in steel yards. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film opens with a dramatised scene of an injured man caught beneath a steel beam due to the carelessness of a workmate. It shows footage of correct methods of stacking and storing steel beams, angles and plates, as well as demonstrating correct use of lifting equipment.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be strained
results.creator_credit: Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1963 film illustrates techniques for manual handling to avoid muscle strain. The film shows workers in various factories undertaking manual labour, and includes footage of an officer of the New South Wales Department of Public Health instructing workers on the correct methods of lifting to avoid injuries such as muscle strain, slipped discs and hernias. The film applies these methods of lifting to other scenarios, including a woman at a filing cabinet, a woman putting out the washing and a postman bending to a letterbox. The narrator refers to ‘the human machine’ throughout the film.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't Be Scalped
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
In this 1960 film, we see female machine operators working in factories. The film focuses on a woman named Judy, describing her outfit and the dangers associated with wearing high-heeled shoes, full skirts, jewellery and long hair while operating a machine. The film then shows Judy dressed in the correct clothing options, including protective shoes, coveralls and cap to cover her hair. It also gives advice on how to lift heavy objects. As opposed to the safety films directed at male workers, the narrator focuses on physical appearance throughout the film, describing Judy as attractive, charming and pretty, and warning against fatigue, wear on clothing, disfigurement and scalping.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be sawed
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1961 film demonstrates the regulations for circular saws in industry, with footage of workers and machines in factories. The instructional narration describes the hazards associated with circular saws and the requirements for guards and safety equipment, warning of the dangers of faulty or unprotected equipment. Alongside the didactic instruction, the film contains melodramatic footage of fingers covered in fake blood and a man pretending to be impaled with a stake of wood.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be let down
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1960 government film describes the regulations under the New South Wales Scaffolding and Lifts Act and how they apply in the building industry. Accompanied by an instructional narration, it surveys the correct manufacture, use and storage of wooden ladders in the industry. It outlines the dangers of improper use of ladders, including dramatic stagings of accidental falls through carelessness.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be cut up
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1959 film outlines the hazards associated with the metal trade industry. It emphasises the importance of fixed guards on machines including guillotines, bending brakes, power presses and emery wheels. The film is interspersed with title cards including the repeated ‘Accidents need not happen’ and features a voiceover narration dramatically warning against accidents. It is directed at both workers in the factory risking accident and disability, and employers risking loss of production and financial loss.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

It emphasises the importance of fixed guards on machines including guillotines, bending brakes, power presses and emery wheels. The film is interspersed with title cards including the repeated ‘Accidents need not happen’ and features a voiceover narration dramatically warning against accidents. It is directed at both workers in the factory risking accident and disability, and employers risking loss of production and financial loss.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains three distinct scenes. The first is footage of an arts and crafts show, including jewellery, pottery and sculpture on display; the second is a man weaving a basket; and the third shows children and adolescents in a gymnastics class, practising somersaults, cartwheels and back flips.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 displays of jewellery and pottery
00:00:55:00 a girl in white cat eye glasses
00:01:51:00 a man basket weaving
00:02:28:00 a group of children and adolescents practising somersaults in a gymnastics class
00:04:05:00 cartwheels and back flips
